comments: T(n,0) + T(n,1) + ... + T(n,n), where T is the array in A026374.Number of lattice paths from (0,0) to the line x=n using steps U=(1,1), D=(1,-1) and, at levels ...-4,-2,0,2,4,..., also H=(2,0). Example: a(2)=5 because we have the following paths from (0,0) to the line x=2: UU, UD, H, DU and DD. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Jan 25 2004From _Gary W. Adamson_, Aug 02 2010: (Start)Equals eigensequence of a triangle with 1's in even columns starting with k=0 and (1, 2, 2, 2,...) in odd columns. Example: a(5) = 50 =(1, 2, 1, 2, 1, 1) dot (1, 1, 2, 5, 10, 25) = (1 + 2 + 2 + 10 + 10 + 25);where (1, 2, 1, 2, 1, 1) = row 5 of the generating triangle. (End)

formula: Also number of integer strings s(0), ...s(n) such that s(0) = 0, where, for 1<=i<=n, s(i) is even if i is even and |s(i)-s(i-1)|<=1.a(2n)=5^n, a(2n+1)=2*5^n. G.f.=(1+2z)/(1-5z^2). - _Emeric Deutsch_, Jan 25 2004Second inverse binomial transform of Fib(3n+3)/2. a(n)=5^(n/2)((1/2+1/sqrt(5))+(1/2-1/sqrt(5))(-1)^n) - _Paul Barry_, Apr 16 2004a(n)=a(n-1)+2a(n-2)+5^floor((n-2)/2); a(n)=sum{k=0..floor(n/2), binomial(floor(n/2), k)2^(n-2k) }. - _Paul Barry_, Jul 14 2004a(n+3) = a(n+2)*a(n+1)/a(n). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Mar 04 2011
